name: OHenry - By Courier
body:
It was neither the season nor the hour when the Park had frequenters; and it is
likely that the young lady, who was seated on one of the benches at the side of
the walk, had merely obeyed a sudden impulse to sit for a while and enjoy a
foretaste of coming Spring.


She rested there, pensive and still. A certain melancholy that touched her
countenance must have been of recent birth, for it had not yet altered the fine
and youthful contours of her cheek, nor subdued the arch though resolute curve
of her lips.


A tall young man came striding through the park along the path near which she
sat. Behind him tagged a boy carrying a suit-case. At sight of the young lady,
the manâs face changed to red and back to pale again. He watched her
countenance as he drew nearer, with hope and anxiety mingled on his own. He
passed within a few yards of her, but he saw no evidence that she was aware of
his presence or existence.


Some fifty yards further on he suddenly stopped and sat on a bench at one side.
The boy dropped the suit-case and stared at him with wondering, shrewd eyes.
The young man took out his handkerchief and wiped his brow. It was a good
handkerchief, a good brow, and the young man was good to look at. He said to
the boy:


âI want you to take a message to that young lady on that bench. Tell her
I am on my way to the station, to leave for San Francisco, where I shall join
that Alaska moose-hunting expedition. Tell her that, since she has commanded me
neither to speak nor to write to her, I take this means of making one last
appeal to her sense of justice, for the sake of what has been. Tell her that to
condemn and discard one who has not deserved such treatment, without giving him
her reasons or a chance to explain is contrary to her nature as I believe it to
be. Tell her that I have thus, to a certain degree, disobeyed her injunctions,
in the hope that she may yet be inclined to see justice done. Go, and tell her
that.â


The young man dropped a half-dollar into the boyâs hand. The boy looked
at him for a moment with bright, canny eyes out of a dirty, intelligent face,
and then set off at a run. He approached the lady on the bench a little
doubtfully, but unembarrassed. He touched the brim of the old plaid bicycle cap
perched on the back of his head. The lady looked at him coolly, without
prejudice or favour.


âLady,â he said, âdat gent on de oder bench sent yer a song
and dance by me. If yer donât know de guy, and heâs tryinâ to
do de Johnny act, say de word, and Iâll call a cop in târee
minutes. If yer does know him, and heâs on de square, wây
Iâll spiel yer de bunch of hot air he sent yer.â


The young lady betrayed a faint interest.


âA song and dance!â she said, in a deliberate sweet voice that
seemed to clothe her words in a diaphanous garment of impalpable irony.
âA new ideaâin the troubadour line, I suppose. Iâused to know
the gentleman who sent you, so I think it will hardly be necessary to call the
police. You may execute your song and dance, but do not sing too loudly. It is
a little early yet for open-air vaudeville, and we might attract
attention.â


âAwe,â said the boy, with a shrug down the length of him,
âyer know what I mean, lady. âTainât a turn, itâs wind.
He told me to tell yer heâs got his collars and cuffs in dat grip for a
scoot clean out to âFrisco. Den heâs goinâ to shoot
snow-birds in de Klondike. He says yer told him not to send âround no
more pink notes nor come hanginâ over de garden gate, and he takes dis
means of puttinâ yer wise. He says yer refereed him out like a has-been,
and never give him no chance to kick at de decision. He says yer swiped him,
and never said why.â


The slightly awakened interest in the young ladyâs eyes did not abate.
Perhaps it was caused by either the originality or the audacity of the
snow-bird hunter, in thus circumventing her express commands against the
ordinary modes of communication. She fixed her eye on a statue standing
disconsolate in the dishevelled park, and spoke into the transmitter:


âTell the gentleman that I need not repeat to him a description of my
ideals. He knows what they have been and what they still are. So far as they
touch on this case, absolute loyalty and truth are the ones paramount. Tell him
that I have studied my own heart as well as one can, and I know its weakness as
well as I do its needs. That is why I decline to hear his pleas, whatever they
may be. I did not condemn him through hearsay or doubtful evidence, and that is
why I made no charge. But, since he persists in hearing what he already well
knows, you may convey the matter.


âTell him that I entered the conservatory that evening from the rear, to
cut a rose for my mother. Tell him I saw him and Miss Ashburton beneath the
pink oleander. The tableau was pretty, but the pose and juxtaposition were too
eloquent and evident to require explanation. I left the conservatory, and, at
the same time, the rose and my ideal. You may carry that song and dance to your
impresario.â


âIâm shy on one word, lady. Juxâjuxâput me wise on dat,
will yer?â


âJuxtapositionâor you may call it propinquityâor, if you
like, being rather too near for one maintaining the position of an
ideal.â


The gravel spun from beneath the boyâs feet. He stood by the other bench.
The manâs eyes interrogated him, hungrily. The boyâs were shining
with the impersonal zeal of the translator.


âDe lady says dat sheâs on to de fact dat gals is dead easy when a
feller comes spielinâ ghost stories and tryinâ to make up, and
datâs why she wonât listen to no soft-soap. She says she caught yer
dead to rights, hugginâ a bunch oâ calico in de hot-house. She
side-stepped in to pull some posies and yer was squeezinâ de oder gal to
beat de band. She says it looked cute, all right all right, but it made her
sick. She says yer better git busy, and make a sneak for de train.â


The young man gave a low whistle and his eyes flashed with a sudden thought.
His hand flew to the inside pocket of his coat, and drew out a handful of
letters. Selecting one, he handed it to the boy, following it with a silver
dollar from his vest-pocket.


âGive that letter to the lady,â he said, âand ask her to read
it. Tell her that it should explain the situation. Tell her that, if she had
mingled a little trust with her conception of the ideal, much heartache might
have been avoided. Tell her that the loyalty she prizes so much has never
wavered. Tell her I am waiting for an answer.â


The messenger stood before the lady.


âDe gent says heâs had de ski-bunk put on him widout no cause. He
says heâs no bum guy; and, lady, yer read dat letter, and Iâll bet
yer heâs a white sport, all right.â


The young lady unfolded the letter; somewhat doubtfully, and read it.


The young lady refolded the letter, and handed it to the boy.


âDe gent wants an answer,â said the messenger. âWotâs
de word?â


The ladyâs eyes suddenly flashed on him, bright, smiling and wet.


âTell that guy on the other bench,â she said, with a happy,
tremulous laugh, âthat his girl wants him.â
